quizzes.title: Knowledge Quiz: Bach and Actor
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Knowledge, actor, bet. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What does the Arabic term, Maghrib represent?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sunset prayers

questions.question: At what temperature does water begin to boil on top of Mount Everest?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 150 degrees Fahrenheit

questions.question: What do Lou Gehrig, the four Beatles, Beethoven, Bach and Mr. Spock have in common?

options.text: They have stars on the New York City Walk of Fame.
They are enshrined in the US Hall of Fame in New York City.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: They are asteroids.

questions.question: Widely known as Crazy Bet, she was a famous Union spy in the American Civil War.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Elizabeth Van Lew

questions.question: The Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act, which established the United States Civil Service Commission, was drafted during the office of which President?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Chester A. Arthur

questions.question: The melody of which 1951 pop song was written by a politician who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize?

options.text: I Cant Help Falling in Love With You

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All in the Game

questions.question: This actor played Murphy Brown’s son in the Murphy Brown sitcom.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Haley Joel Osmont

questions.question: What do you add to steel to make it stainless?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Chromium

questions.question: Which singer led The Nude Tour?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Prince

questions.question: This is the name of the computer program developed by the Hollywood division of the Los Angeles Police Department to create a  database of crimes, criminals, and all related information.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: HITMAN

questions.question: How did Michael Moore finance his movie „Roger and Me?”

options.text: He sold over 100% of the film to investors
He managed a Walmart in Flint, Michigan.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He ran bingo games.

questions.question: He was the first NHL player to buy his former team.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mario Lemieux

questions.question: This word can mean to jump straight up or a foolish and/or weak person.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pronk

questions.question: U.S. antitrust lawyers took Microsoft to court claiming that the company tried to use its monopolistic power to destroy this computer language.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: JAVA

questions.question: Which super computer lost a match to Garry Kasparov?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Deep Blue

quizzes.title: Sports Quiz: Philosopher and Thesis
quizzes.description: Test your sports knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Sports, bloomsday, process. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This Irish playwright, novelist and poet wrote the following line in his famous play Waiting for Godot: We are all born mad. Some remain so.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Samuel Beckett

questions.question: This city, known also as Anvil City, is situated  in Northwest Alaska.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nome

questions.question: This medical term refers to a disease-causing protein agent that contains no genetic material.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Prion

questions.question: The famous Japanese cherry trees were planted in Washington, D.C., around the Tidal Basin at the request of which US First Lady?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Helen Taft

questions.question: What does the Latin phrase ceteris paribus mean?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All other things being equal

questions.question: The Walden Pond, made famous by writer, naturalist, and philosopher Henry David Thoreau, is located in which US state?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Massachusetts

questions.question: The dialectic of this philosopher is most often characterized as a three-step process of  thesis, antithesis, synthesis. According to his concept, a thesis would cause the creation of its antithesis and this would eventually result in a synthesis.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hegel

questions.question: Bloomsday is a secular holiday, which commemorates the life of Irish writer James Joyce and the fictitious events in his novel Ulysses. Bloomsday is celebrated annually, on what date?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: June 16

questions.question: You are given a bag with 10 marbles, four red marbles and six blue marbles. You select one at random. What is the probability  that the marble you select is either blue or green?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 6 out of ten

questions.question: What does the Latin proverb, Dum spiro, spero, mean in English?

options.text: Do to others the same as you do to yourself.
I know that I dont know anything.
Dont look a gift horse in the mouth.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: While I breath, I hope

questions.question: Easter Island, an island in the south Pacific Ocean, is a territory of which country?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Chile

questions.question: This soul singer and songwriter, often called Silky Smooth because of his rich baritone, is famous for his hits Rainy Night in Georgia, Fools Rush In, This Time of the Year.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Brook Benton

questions.question: The standing long jump and the standing high jump were once Olympic sports.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: This French mathematician, physicist, and religious philosopher, author of the Lettres provinciales, stated the following: There are truths on this side of the Pyranees, which are falsehoods on the other.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Blaise Pascal

questions.question: In Freuds psychoanalytic theory, the defense mechanism in which anxiety-producing or unacceptable emotions are replaced by their direct opposites is defined by which term?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Reaction formation

quizzes.title: Knowledge Quiz: State and Clouds
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Knowledge, clouds, tigers. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Who is considered the first American to be killed in the Cold War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Birch

questions.question: Which great composer wrote Wellingtons Victory , which included cannons, drums, and a lot of  brass?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Beethoven

questions.question: The California state flag originally featured a wolf.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: A day on Venus is equal to how many Earth days?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 243

questions.question: What song by The Beatles, recorded during the Sgt. Pepper sessions, contains the lyrics:

options.text: hind the shelter in the middle of a roundabout

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Penny Lane

questions.question: Is it true that starfish can see with the help of the two eyes at the end of each leg?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: No

questions.question: In which US state is the Bicycle Museum of America located?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ohio

questions.question: The purpose of the striped fur of most tigers species is camouflage.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: A fly flies slower when the sun is behind the clouds.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Which animal is the record holder for the largest male genital organ-to-body length ratio in nature?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Slug

questions.question: Queen Elizabeth II was coronated Queen in 1953. Whom did she directly succeed?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George VI

questions.question: Which statement is untrue about Luxembourg?

options.text: Its original wealth came from the iron mines in the region.
Its capital, Esch-sur-Alzette, is not its largest city.
It is often grouped with the Benelux group of European nations.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Its capital, Esch-sur-Alzette, is not its largest city.

questions.question: Which of these famous Russian politicians was also famed as a literary critic?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Trotsky

questions.question: Which was the first sub-Saharan African nation to gain its freedom?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ghana

questions.question: This Russian city, founded by Grand Duke George II of Russia in 1221, was called Gorky from 1932 to 1990.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nizhny Novgorod

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: United Colors of Benetton

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Czech Republic

questions.question: Which was the first racehorse to run the Kentucky Derby in less than 2 minutes?

questions.question: What is the correct formal name of the country known as the UK?

options.text: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
United Kingdom of England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland
Union of Kingdoms of England and Scotland

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

questions.question: What city is the capital of the European Union?

options.text: The EU has no official capital.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The EU has no official capital.

questions.question: Which English king had wives called Catherine, Anne, Jane, Anne, Catherine and Catherine, in that order?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Henry the Eighth

questions.question: Which of the following political figures was the first to fight a war as President of the United States?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Thomas Jefferson

questions.question: In 1078, a battle between two rulers was averted because of a chess game.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: This song about a paralyzed war veteran whose wife cheats on him was written by Mel Tillis and performed by Kenny Rogers and the First Edition in 1969. It has also been recorded by CAKE, The Killers, Waylon Jennings, Roger Miller and Wolfsheim.

options.text: Leave the Bourbon on the Shelf
Ruby, Dont Take Your Love to Town

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ruby, Dont Take Your Love to Town

questions.question: This novella by H.P. Lovecraft was published in 1936 and is about a hybrid race of human/ fish/ frog people who inhabit a small town in Massachusetts.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Shadow Over Innsmouth

questions.question: How many colonies formed United States of America in 1776?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 13

questions.question: Twilight Zone is a term used by the United States Air Force to describe the border between day and night on a planetary body.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

quizzes.description: Test your science knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Science, nickname, kind. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Crimson tea

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

options.text: The first Friday of the year
